1231 Wins Union Vote
Local 1231 of the Laborers' International Union polled 191 votes,
more than either of its competitors
in last Friday's union election at
Hopkins, but failed to win a majority.
The Laborers' chief rival, by most
informeC pre-election predictions,
was Local 1199E of the Hospital
and Nursing Home Employees Union.
But Local 1199 drew only 70 votes
to 121 for no union representation

at all.
Local 1231 needed 205 votes for a
majority, which would have given
clear title to certification as
bargaining agent for University nonprofessional employees. Now the
door is open to a runoff election
between Local 1231 and no union
representation.
However, twenty-seven ballots were
challenged in the election. If the
State Department of Labor and Industry, which oversaw the election,
awards 14 or more of the challenges
to Local 1231, there will be no runoff and 1231 will be declared the
winner. A decision on the challenges
is expected this afternoon.
A total of 409 ballots were cast by

a bargaining unit numbering 468
employees. "We want to thank all
the employees who took time out
to vote in the election," said John
DiFebo, International Representative
for the Laborers' Union. "We feel
those who voted for 1199 will vote
for 1231," he continued,"if a runoff
election is necessary."
A spokesman for Local 1199E
declined to comment on the election.
DiFebo promised that 1231, if
certified, would "definitely" ask the
Administration to boost workers'
wages, and include provisions for
cost of living increases in a negotiated contract.
Joseph Rumberger, Hopkins Director of Personnel Services, refused to
predict the outcome of the election.
"The vote is close enough that I
wouldn't make any predictions," he
stated. The basic question involved
with the challenged ballots, he said,
is whether they were cast by legitimately eligible voters. "Reportedly
the state made most" of the challenges, Rumberger claimed.

By JOHN HOLLIS
Ever been to a circus? Of course you have.
Everyone has. But a few weekends ago I went to a
different kind of circus - no spangled trapeze girls,
no tigers and white horses.The only things similar
to - Barnum's spectacle were the three rings and
the plethora of clowns.
The circus I attended was officially titled the
National Conference on Political Justice, though
the National Exhibition of Leftist Political Turmoil
would have been more appropriate. It was probably the same as any such gathering -- they all
reveal the conflicts, disputes and insecurities of
the left.
In the center ring of this political circus was a
panel of four. William Kunstler, defender of H.
Rap Brown and the Chicago 7, was the star attraction. Melvin Wulf, Legal Director of the American Civil Liberties Union, was there. And two
unknowns: Jerry Mandel, professor of sociology at
Sonoma State University, and Robert Mozenter,
Philadelphia Assistant District Attorney for narcotics and rackets (the conference was held at the
University of Pennsylvania.) Mozenter was the
token conservative, to "balance" the panel. Halfway through the festivities Charles Garry made a
surprise appearance. Garry, national lawyer for
the Black Panther Party, is presently defending
Bobby Seale on a New Haven murder charge.

In The Road
Star attraction Kunstler opened the show. First
he read part of Jerry Rubin's book "Dolt!", then
proceeded to proclaim Rubin's seriousness,while
throwing out jokes about Julius Hoffman.If Kunstler did say anything about American problems it
was so simplistic and obvious as to be pathetically
meaningless - "Chicago cops and Southern sheriffs
pick on long-hairs and blacks", etc. Very disappointing.
Then Melvin Wulf spoke, addressing the crowd
of over one thousand in a voice so flat and pedantic
that everyone was soon asleep. As his speechwas
distinguished by a total lack of anything memorable, I have forgotten what he said.
Long-haired pseudo-freak Jerry Mandel was
next, putting down Philadelphia and telling inexcusable jokes. A few days before, immediately
after his arrival, Mandel's two traveling companions were busted for possession, and he had
spent the time between then and the Conference
tripping, staring out of his hotelwindow for police.
He was the third strike - the Conference was uninformative and boring, even a failure as a circus.
At this point, with the words of closing speaker
Mozenter, the spotlight shifted to the other two
rings of the circus, the audience. The rest of the
show was amusing, chaotic, disturbing, tragic.

Doing His Job
Philadelphia's chief narc, Mozenter began by
describing how unfair the drug laws are, which
is like trying to convince the Ecumenical Council
that God exists.(He has since resigned in protest
of harsh penalties for drug violators.) Random
heckling bothered him, he paused. "Look, I'm a
young fellow myself and I'm just doing my job."
You didn't really say that, did you? Too late now.
The crowd's reaction to Mozenter's unfortunate
choice of words need not be described. After the
noise subsided the audience realized that they
had just done and could do,that the panel was boring and their own shouts and jeers were more
entertaining. It was like a rock concert, where
the people in the seats are often more fascinating than the people on stage.
As expected, the auditorium was filled with
an almost all-white under-25 crowd, mostly Penn
students. Because of this about twenty Panthers
showed up. Specializing in high-pressure salesmanship and the production of an awful newspaper,

the Panthers strenuously endeavored to collect
money. Throughout the carnival a female Panther
at the back would loudly shout "right on!" whenever anyone cheered, that is, about every thirty
seconds.

Two More Rings
After Mozenter had declared his Eichmannesque
devotion to duty the main topic of discussion became whether he should be allowed to continue
his speech. This split the crowd circus into its
two rings - on one side the liberals in favor of
parliamentary courtesy and FirstAmendmentprotection for all, on the other side the radicals fed
up with the bullshit.
Yes, it's in the Constitution - free speech for
all. But if the Constitution means nothingto Julius
Hoffman, John Murtagh, John Mitchell, Harrold
Carswell, et al., how can it mean anythingto people who know how unjust the laws can be?
True, it's a courtesy liberals pride themselves
on - letting the opposition speak. But this little
nicety is plainly hypocritical, as no self-respecting liberal listens to what the opposition says anyway. And the time has come to stop being courteous
with cops, narcs, and their political bosses. How
much courtesy has Ronald Reagon shown toward
California students? How courteous was Richard
Daley in August, 1968? (you DO remember, don't
you?) How much longer will masochistic white
liberals continue to hold worthless meetings while
people are sent to prison? Ask Fred Hampton about
courtesy, he'll tell you.

Inside or Out
Further babbling from the stage cleaved the
gathering even more into liberals vs. radicals.
The issue became the abstract question of whether
political and social change should be implemented
by working within the established system or outside of that system. An extremely crucial question. No talk about the changes,just about how they
should be accomplished. Wulf insisted that the
battles had to be won in court. Finally allowed to
speak (i.e. ignored), Mozenter advocated the election of the right representatives to legislatures,
advocated with such urgent freqency that I began
to wait for his announcement of candidacy. Kunstler was magnificently ambivalent on this point.
Charles Garry's views regardingthis topicwere
most interesting. In emotional and colorful language he expressed his disgust and frustration after
many years of facing the Julius Hoffmans of
America. He's seen the system liberals want to
work within.He knows what an intolerably long
time change takes,that reforms are often corrupted or diluted, that progress may just as likely be
backward as forward. There is no need to mention
examples of this.

Burn and Build
To paraphrase, Garry's message was this: burn
and build. And you can't accomplish the building
without doing the burning first.
Liberals in the crowd considered Garry a
demagogue and resented his unannounced appearance. Radicals cheered and whistled, their most
revolutionary actions to date. Liberals, I suggest,
should see "Z" and think carefully about what
happened to the Greek pacifists who tried to work
by the established rules. Ask GregOrios Lambrakis
about courtesy, he'll tell you.
Will all of those who agree that change is
necessary ever concur on the methods to achieve
those changes? The circus convinced me that while
that day is coming closer it's still along way off.
Clinging to noble principles, idealists and liberals
shudder at the thought of revolutionary tactics. But
few of them have discovered how difficult it is to
rationally discuss politics with a man swinging a
club.
It was just another circus, perhaps. Not the greatest show on earth, but one of the saddest.

Wadleigh and Maurice: Ready
For The Moment When It Came
Most movies consist of someone looking—through a camera
—at someone else, or something
else. "Woodstock" consists of the
young — performers and audience, together—looking at themselves. It wasn't planned that
way. It came out that way because the moment had arrived.
Producer Bob Maurice and director Mike Wadleigh were ready
when it came. They had called
together a gifted team of young
cameramen and technicians. And
collected a half-million worth of
the finest movie equipment.
When what happened started to
happen, they thrust the whole
assemblage straight into the heart
of the Woodstock Fair. Through
three great rainstorms, tides of
mud, 70 hours of shooting, 81
hours of sound takes, 400,000
people, three day-and-night days
of discomfort, communion and
release, they caught on film and
tape for all of history the unbelievable true mass experience of
Bethel, N.Y.

Six months of slow creative
agony followed. Over 315,000
feet of film (120 hours if shown
straight) were reworked on new
and profoundly sophisticated editing equipment, called Kellers,
which allows as many as six views
of the same subject to be seen at
once. More important than the
technical advantage is the simultaneity, as near the quick-silver
shift and shimmer of life itself as
a machine can yield.
Wadleigh, paired by assistant
directors-supervising editors
Martin Scorsese and Thelma
Schoonmaker, with producer
Maurice on hand to worry, rode
the sea of tape and film through
the Kellers. Like a group of great
surfers facing in to an ocean up
to now unknown. They emerged
with three hours, 10 minutes of
phenomenon that goes by the
name of "Woodstock."
It is a movie, of course, and it
is being released by a movie company, Warner Bros. It may well
turn out to be a forking-point for
life in America.

When Joan Baez is dealing
with words, per se, she puts them
in a book ("Daybreak"), or in a
speech on civil rights or the peace
movement. When she sings, she
concerns herself with something
else. "I don't care very much
about where a song came from
or why, or even what it says. All
I care about is how it sounds and
the feeling in it," she states.
For her, the Woodstock Music & Art Fair was a time of great
feeling. She was a few weeks
away from the birth of her first
child. The father, her husband,
David, was in a Federal prison
serving a five-year sentence for
draft refusal. She sang, hauntingly, of both.
She has that uncanny power,
to hold and fuse many into one
with herself. And because of it
she has become, since her initial
professional appearance at Newport in 1959, the most significant
woman in the folk field. All of
her previous eleven albums for
Vanguard were, and are, bestsellers.
The newest is named "David's
Album." And her child is named
Gabriel. Gabriel is David's cellmate in Safford Prison Farm,
Arizona.

By JOHN HOLLIS
Ever been to a circus? Of course you have.
Everyone has. But a few weekends ago I went to a
different kind of circus - no spangled trapeze girls,
no tigers and white horses.The only things similar
to - Barnum's spectacle were the three rings and
the plethora of clowns.
The circus I attended was officially titled the
National Conference on Political Justice, though
the National Exhibition of Leftist Political Turmoil
would have been more appropriate. It was probably the same as any such gathering -- they all
reveal the conflicts, disputes and insecurities of
the left.
In the center ring of this political circus was a
panel of four. William Kunstler, defender of H.
Rap Brown and the Chicago 7, was the star attraction. Melvin Wulf, Legal Director of the American Civil Liberties Union, was there. And two
unknowns: Jerry Mandel, professor of sociology at
Sonoma State University, and Robert Mozenter,
Philadelphia Assistant District Attorney for narcotics and rackets (the conference was held at the
University of Pennsylvania.) Mozenter was the
token conservative, to "balance" the panel. Halfway through the festivities Charles Garry made a
surprise appearance. Garry, national lawyer for
the Black Panther Party, is presently defending
Bobby Seale on a New Haven murder charge.

In The Road
Star attraction Kunstler opened the show. First
he read part of Jerry Rubin's book "Dolt!", then
proceeded to proclaim Rubin's seriousness,while
throwing out jokes about Julius Hoffman.If Kunstler did say anything about American problems it
was so simplistic and obvious as to be pathetically
meaningless - "Chicago cops and Southern sheriffs
pick on long-hairs and blacks", etc. Very disappointing.
Then Melvin Wulf spoke, addressing the crowd
of over one thousand in a voice so flat and pedantic
that everyone was soon asleep. As his speechwas
distinguished by a total lack of anything memorable, I have forgotten what he said.
Long-haired pseudo-freak Jerry Mandel was
next, putting down Philadelphia and telling inexcusable jokes. A few days before, immediately
after his arrival, Mandel's two traveling companions were busted for possession, and he had
spent the time between then and the Conference
tripping, staring out of his hotelwindow for police.
He was the third strike - the Conference was uninformative and boring, even a failure as a circus.
At this point, with the words of closing speaker
Mozenter, the spotlight shifted to the other two
rings of the circus, the audience. The rest of the
show was amusing, chaotic, disturbing, tragic.

Doing His Job
Philadelphia's chief narc, Mozenter began by
describing how unfair the drug laws are, which
is like trying to convince the Ecumenical Council
that God exists.(He has since resigned in protest
of harsh penalties for drug violators.) Random
heckling bothered him, he paused. "Look, I'm a
young fellow myself and I'm just doing my job."
You didn't really say that, did you? Too late now.
The crowd's reaction to Mozenter's unfortunate
choice of words need not be described. After the
noise subsided the audience realized that they
had just done and could do,that the panel was boring and their own shouts and jeers were more
entertaining. It was like a rock concert, where
the people in the seats are often more fascinating than the people on stage.
As expected, the auditorium was filled with
an almost all-white under-25 crowd, mostly Penn
students. Because of this about twenty Panthers
showed up. Specializing in high-pressure salesmanship and the production of an awful newspaper,

the Panthers strenuously endeavored to collect
money. Throughout the carnival a female Panther
at the back would loudly shout "right on!" whenever anyone cheered, that is, about every thirty
seconds.

Two More Rings
After Mozenter had declared his Eichmannesque
devotion to duty the main topic of discussion became whether he should be allowed to continue
his speech. This split the crowd circus into its
two rings - on one side the liberals in favor of
parliamentary courtesy and FirstAmendmentprotection for all, on the other side the radicals fed
up with the bullshit.
Yes, it's in the Constitution - free speech for
all. But if the Constitution means nothingto Julius
Hoffman, John Murtagh, John Mitchell, Harrold
Carswell, et al., how can it mean anythingto people who know how unjust the laws can be?
True, it's a courtesy liberals pride themselves
on - letting the opposition speak. But this little
nicety is plainly hypocritical, as no self-respecting liberal listens to what the opposition says anyway. And the time has come to stop being courteous
with cops, narcs, and their political bosses. How
much courtesy has Ronald Reagon shown toward
California students? How courteous was Richard
Daley in August, 1968? (you DO remember, don't
you?) How much longer will masochistic white
liberals continue to hold worthless meetings while
people are sent to prison? Ask Fred Hampton about
courtesy, he'll tell you.

Inside or Out
Further babbling from the stage cleaved the
gathering even more into liberals vs. radicals.
The issue became the abstract question of whether
political and social change should be implemented
by working within the established system or outside of that system. An extremely crucial question. No talk about the changes,just about how they
should be accomplished. Wulf insisted that the
battles had to be won in court. Finally allowed to
speak (i.e. ignored), Mozenter advocated the election of the right representatives to legislatures,
advocated with such urgent freqency that I began
to wait for his announcement of candidacy. Kunstler was magnificently ambivalent on this point.
Charles Garry's views regardingthis topicwere
most interesting. In emotional and colorful language he expressed his disgust and frustration after
many years of facing the Julius Hoffmans of
America. He's seen the system liberals want to
work within.He knows what an intolerably long
time change takes,that reforms are often corrupted or diluted, that progress may just as likely be
backward as forward. There is no need to mention
examples of this.

Burn and Build
To paraphrase, Garry's message was this: burn
and build. And you can't accomplish the building
without doing the burning first.
Liberals in the crowd considered Garry a
demagogue and resented his unannounced appearance. Radicals cheered and whistled, their most
revolutionary actions to date. Liberals, I suggest,
should see "Z" and think carefully about what
happened to the Greek pacifists who tried to work
by the established rules. Ask GregOrios Lambrakis
about courtesy, he'll tell you.
Will all of those who agree that change is
necessary ever concur on the methods to achieve
those changes? The circus convinced me that while
that day is coming closer it's still along way off.
Clinging to noble principles, idealists and liberals
shudder at the thought of revolutionary tactics. But
few of them have discovered how difficult it is to
rationally discuss politics with a man swinging a
club.
It was just another circus, perhaps. Not the greatest show on earth, but one of the saddest.

Most movies consist of someone looking—through a camera

together a gifted team of young
cameramen and technicians. And
collected a half-million worth of
the finest movie equipment.
When what happened started to
happen, they thrust the whole
assemblage straight into the heart
of the Woodstock Fair. Through
three great rainstorms, tides of
mud, 70 hours of shooting, 81
hours of sound takes, 400,000
people, three day-and-night days
of discomfort, communion and
release, they caught on film and
tape for all of history the unbelievable true mass experience of
Bethel, N.Y.

Six months of slow creative
agony followed. Over 315,000
feet of film (120 hours if shown
straight) were reworked on new
and profoundly sophisticated editing equipment, called Kellers,
which allows as many as six views
of the same subject to be seen at
once. More important than the
technical advantage is the simultaneity, as near the quick-silver
shift and shimmer of life itself as
a machine can yield.
Wadleigh, paired by assistant
directors-supervising editors
Martin Scorsese and Thelma
Schoonmaker, with producer
Maurice on hand to worry, rode
the sea of tape and film through
the Kellers. Like a group of great
surfers facing in to an ocean up
to now unknown. They emerged
with three hours, 10 minutes of
phenomenon that goes by the

It is a movie, of course, and it

With the odds stacked mightily against a bearable future, there's
a turbulent current of hope crackling through these times. The way
out of here comes down to a genuine love we create and follow with
a yearning, painful, fierce persistence. Look far enough over yonder
and it's a new world coming and somehow the way up has something
to do with going back to where we once belonged. Joy is alive and well
in rock and roll.
Everyone I know feels it. Myths are fading, minds in motion conjure joy and let it be, values come to resemble feelings more than
things, there is new music and life at its best is its dance. A feeling,
yes. It culminates periodically in successive bursts of pure positive
energy generated by ever increasing numbers of new children together, reciprocating their music. Woodstock was one of them, the
biggest most beautiful one yet.
At Woodstock where it all came together, close to the earth, under
the sky, breathing clean air we sustained it for three days. Even the
rain that threatened to stop it while challenging us to see it through
was a part of it. The challenge was met, the show went on, the stage
was several hundred acres of mother nature. A lineup of the most
star spangled, full blasting rock and roll extravagance was up on the
proscenium, but the star of Woodstock was you, you who were there,
you who tried to come, you who wished you had, you who heard about
it and were flashed with the magnificence and monstrosity of it all.
What emerged was a glimpse of the future, a three day tribal celebration burst full blown from the heights of its fantasies and the
depths of its most gruesome fears. It literally rocked the outside world.
But to many here among us it was no surprise. Somehow it was
destined, a great leap in the continuum was upon us. The energy and
ingredients had been growing geometrically, countless pop events
prior to Woodstock approached, even touched transcendence, but
this one turned out to be the chosen moment. Why then? Why there?
Examining the coordinates is missing the point. By luck, by magic, by
sheer gumption, it happened at Woodstock.
Urgency, ecstasy, idealism, terror. That's what ticks like a time
bomb inside this generation. Music and massacre exist side by side in
time. Woodstock was an equal and opposite reaction to the technological, social and political pressure cooker we live in. Civilization has
a tantrum, youth has a rock festival.
It became a three day live-in where food, shelter and joy were
shared. Authority was missing in action, hundreds of thousands of
young people suddenly realized they could have it any way they
wanted. A choice was made; genuine peace, love and humanity prevailed. It worked. Joyously, profoundly, we were all touched by one
another en masse for the duration of a festival after which nothing
could ever be the same. It became a microcosm of a once and future
dream, a metaphor for a movement, a statement on all the changes
we feel. It was an eruption of energy so positive and logistically monumental that come what may, it stands as the best example of just how
together we can be. Everyone.
